newsitem.title: USA: Farmers fight to keep ethanol subsidy.
newsitem.headline: Farmers fight to keep ethanol subsidy.

text.p: American farmers are fighting to hang on to a tax break for ethanol that experts say is worth billions of dollars a year.

Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the powerful tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, has zeroed in on the subsidy as a way to raise money to offset tax cuts called for in the balanced budget plan.
The Texas Republican says Uncle Sam could get upwards of $600 million a year in tax revenue if the ethanol credit is scrapped.

But ethanol producers say the move would pull the rug out from under a fledgling industry. Farmers fear it will send corn prices tumbling since ethanol, which is made from corn, accounts for more than 5 percent of their market.

"If you yank the subsidy, ethanol would no longer be profitable and would cost corn growers around $5 billion a year because the price of corn would drop sharply," said Michael Evans, professor of economics at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.
Currently, oil companies get a tax credit of 5.4 cents per gallon when they blend clean-burning ethanol with gasoline.

The subsidy was born out of the 1970's oil crisis when the government wanted to provide incentives to producers of alternative fuels. In 1990, Congress passed a law guaranteeing the tax credit until the year 2000, encouraging more companies to get into the ethanol market.
Archer has been gunning for the tax break for years. In 1995, the provision narrowly escaped the chairman's budget chopping block when House Speaker Newt Gingrich stepped in.

"I have long considered the ethanol subsidy to be a wasteful use of tax dollars. The subsidy has failed to achieve its desired environmental or energy-related intentions, while penalising taxpayers by removing money from our nation's roads, bridges, and infastructure," Archer said recently.

He got ammunition in March from a General Accounting Office report that found while ethanol tax incentives had helped boost corn prices for farmers they had done little to help the environment or to achieve energy independence.

But an Agriculture Department report released this year predicted eliminating the tax break would boost the U.S. trade deficit by as much as $7.8 billion during fiscal years 1998-2005 due to larger oil imports. It also would reduce cash receipts by farmers by $12 billion to $20.8 billion during that period, the report said.
Archer's assault strikes a nerve with farmers who saw most federal farm subsidies disappear in last year's overhaul of U.S. agriculture policy. Ethanol producers also cry foul.

"This was a deal that was made to help a fledgling ethanol industry be competitive with fossil fuels," said Dennis Stolte of the American Farm Bureau Federation. "We think it's unfair and what amounts to reneging on a deal."

"This is a matter of equity," said Steve Cropper, president of Williams Energy Group, the nation's second-largest ethanol producer. "We relied on the current law remaining in place when we made our decision to get into the marketing and manufacturing of ethanol."

The tax break has often been attacked as a give-away for agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland Co., which got into ethanol early and became the dominant producer. ADM now accounts for about 50 percent of the nation's ethanol output.
But backers say in fact it will be the "new guys" that will bear the brunt if the tax break is yanked.

"If you were to take the tax credit away today, when the dust settled, ADM would be left standing," said one industry source who asked not to be identified. "They've been around longest and written everything off. They'd be the likely survivor."
Archer has not decided whether to propose reducing the tax credit or eliminating it all together in the tax package he is expected to unveil in early June.
Last week, 100 House members urged congressional leaders to protect the ethanol tax incentive. Farm lobbyists are hoping Archer's effort will turn out to be a tempest in a teapot.
"I think we will be able to prevail on the Senate side," said Farm Bureau's Stolte. "We'll have a contentious debate over something that may already be dead."
